We read with great interest the article by Brown et al
1 who worked with a multidisciplinary team to deploy a standardized guideline for airway management of coronavirus disease (COVID)â€“positive or unknown patients. We applaud their insight in recognizing the difficulty in implementing a guideline amid the rapid emergence of new information and in adapting the guideline to different environments within the hospital, while still prioritizing the safety of health care providers (HCPs) in the presence of personal protective equipment (PPE) shortage. A long and ever-growing list of HCPs have lost their lives amid the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic.
2 A large proportion of HCPs acquired the infection at the beginning of the outbreak, probably secondary to the lack of awareness of the pathogen and inadequate PPE.
3 Other aspects of infection control are paramount in preventing nosocomial infection, such as strict screening protocols for hospital staff, visitor restrictions, widely available and highly sensitive testing, good hand hygiene, and clear infection prevention and control (IPC) protocols.
